description: Apple Certified Support Professional (ACSP) certification confirms the candidate's understanding of OS X's core functionality as well as having the ability to configure key services, perform basic troubleshooting, and support multiple users  with essential OS X capabilities. Candidates for this course may be in a role of help desk professional, technical coordinator, or power user who supports OS X users, manages networks, or provides technical support for the Mac.
name: Certified Support Professional 10.11
subtitle: OS X Support Essentials 10.11

episodes.description: In this episode Don walks us through the Apple Certified Support Professional certification. He takes a look at the topics covered, as well as basic information on how to take the exam.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.333
[SOUND]

2
00:00:04.333 --> 00:00:09.531
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:09.531 --> 00:00:13.412
In this video, we're gonna take a look at
the Apple Certified Support Professional

4
00:00:13.412 --> 00:00:15.920
certification show, here on ITPROTV.

5
00:00:15.920 --> 00:00:18.970
Now the ACSP's been around for awhile,
we've actually filmed it a few times.

6
00:00:18.970 --> 00:00:22.990
This time we're doing an update to
the El Capitan operating system release.

7
00:00:22.990 --> 00:00:26.870
With each new version of Mac OS,
we get changes, changes to the UI,

8
00:00:26.870 --> 00:00:28.160
changes to the software.

9
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:31.860
And we update to refresh and reflect
that in our certification training.

10
00:00:31.860 --> 00:00:33.457
So that's what we're doing right here.

11
00:00:33.457 --> 00:00:37.497
If you want to learn all about supporting
El Capitan out there in the real world,

12
00:00:37.497 --> 00:00:41.008
if you're trying to support OS 10.11,
this is where it's at.

13
00:00:41.008 --> 00:00:43.320
Now, there's a lot of overlap
with previous versions.

14
00:00:43.320 --> 00:00:45.080
If you're already certified
in a previous version,

15
00:00:45.080 --> 00:00:47.250
you'll find that this is mostly the same.

16
00:00:47.250 --> 00:00:50.760
Just a handful of utilities have changed,
and things that you may encounter.

17
00:00:50.760 --> 00:00:55.950
But on a bigger side, we have some new
security features in OS 10.11 that

18
00:00:55.950 --> 00:00:57.890
can impact how we deploy applications and

19
00:00:57.890 --> 00:00:59.830
support the machines out
there in the real world.

20
00:00:59.830 --> 00:01:04.740
Well, before I get ahead of myself,
let's start with what is the ACSP?

21
00:01:04.740 --> 00:01:09.400
The Apple Certified Support Professional
is a certification designed for anybody

22
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:13.630
who's out there supporting Macintosh
computers in a business environment.

23
00:01:13.630 --> 00:01:14.770
We're not talking about home users.

24
00:01:14.770 --> 00:01:18.320
You might have one, two,
even five Macs at home, and

25
00:01:18.320 --> 00:01:20.660
those you really just
manage them individually.

26
00:01:20.660 --> 00:01:26.420
But when you have a 100 Macs, a 1,000,
when you've got MacBook laptops,

27
00:01:26.420 --> 00:01:29.860
and Mac Pro desktops, and iPads, and
iPhones, and you've got all these

28
00:01:29.860 --> 00:01:33.910
different Apple devices, it sure would be
nice if we had some kind of way to manage

29
00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:37.680
them in a network where they all play
together and, well, perform nicely.

30
00:01:37.680 --> 00:01:40.730
And then when you had problems,
that you knew the steps to go

31
00:01:40.730 --> 00:01:43.920
through to troubleshoot and
resolve those issues without having

32
00:01:43.920 --> 00:01:46.700
to rush right out to the Apple Store and
get them to fix it for you.

33
00:01:46.700 --> 00:01:48.620
That's what the ACSP is all about.

34
00:01:48.620 --> 00:01:51.700
If you're one of those people that's
out there having to support Macs

35
00:01:51.700 --> 00:01:54.210
in your environment,
this is the show for you.

36
00:01:54.210 --> 00:01:56.850
Now, you might have Windows
machines in your environment.

37
00:01:56.850 --> 00:01:58.420
You might have just a handful of Macs, but

38
00:01:58.420 --> 00:02:00.590
there's still a lot you need to
know just to keep them up and

39
00:02:00.590 --> 00:02:04.480
running and healthy, and
that's all stuff that we see right here.

40
00:02:04.480 --> 00:02:07.432
All right, now the ACSP,
it covers a lot of different topics.

41
00:02:07.432 --> 00:02:10.428
It's a bit all over the place.

42
00:02:10.428 --> 00:02:13.910
And the reason is it's part of the whole
certification track from Apple.

43
00:02:13.910 --> 00:02:16.440
So let me bring up Apples's Training and
Certification page here.

44
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:19.610
And what you'll see is that they
have a number of certifications.

45
00:02:19.610 --> 00:02:23.350
And at the time of this filming, some of
them have been updated to El Capitan,

46
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:24.910
some them are still at Yosemite, so

47
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:27.080
you'll see several down here
listed here under Yosemite.

48
00:02:27.080 --> 00:02:28.820
But on the El Capitan side,

49
00:02:28.820 --> 00:02:31.470
we've got the Apple Certified
Support Professional right there.

50
00:02:31.470 --> 00:02:32.790
That's the name of the certification.

51
00:02:32.790 --> 00:02:36.130
When you pass the exam you get your ACSP.

52
00:02:36.130 --> 00:02:37.770
The required exam, though,

53
00:02:37.770 --> 00:02:43.239
is actually called
the OS X Support Essentials 10.11 exam.

54
00:02:43.239 --> 00:02:46.500
And that exam gets updated
with each release of Mac OS.

55
00:02:46.500 --> 00:02:48.730
They have to update to
reflect the new changes.

56
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:53.160
So, if you take this one exam,
you get this one certification, the ACSP.

57
00:02:53.160 --> 00:02:56.190
Now, the ACSP is one certification map.

58
00:02:56.190 --> 00:02:57.800
Well, there's actually two others.

59
00:02:57.800 --> 00:03:02.760
The ACA, or Apple Certified Associate,
that's considered the entry point.

60
00:03:02.760 --> 00:03:05.659
So if you're just getting started
with Apple certifications,

61
00:03:05.659 --> 00:03:08.676
it's better to start with the ACA
than to jump right into the ACSP.

62
00:03:08.676 --> 00:03:12.951
Now, they don't show it here cuz it hasn't
been updated yet, but there's actually two

63
00:03:12.951 --> 00:03:16.790
ACAs right here, Mac Management Basics and
Mac Integration Basics.

64
00:03:16.790 --> 00:03:21.430
One of them focuses just on Macs,
Mac Management Basics.

65
00:03:21.430 --> 00:03:23.430
That one has a lot of
overlap with the ACSP,

66
00:03:23.430 --> 00:03:27.720
so that's a great place to start
before going into the ACSP.

67
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:29.240
Mac Integration Basics, on the other hand,

68
00:03:29.240 --> 00:03:32.610
focuses more on getting Windows
to play nice with Mac OS.

69
00:03:32.610 --> 00:03:35.270
It's not necessarily tied
in to what we do in ACSP.

70
00:03:35.270 --> 00:03:39.044
So if you're just starting out, I do
recommend doing the Mac Management Basics

71
00:03:39.044 --> 00:03:42.500
certification first, and
we've already filmed that here at ITProTV.

72
00:03:42.500 --> 00:03:45.340
It's in our course library,
you can jump right over and watch it.

73
00:03:45.340 --> 00:03:48.747
And even though Apple hasn't updated
it for 10.11 yet, we already have.

74
00:03:48.747 --> 00:03:49.627
So it's in there in 10.11.

75
00:03:49.627 --> 00:03:53.674
I mean, you can go back and watch our 10.9
content, or whatever, if you want, but

76
00:03:53.674 --> 00:03:56.460
we've already updated it for El Capitan.

77
00:03:56.460 --> 00:04:01.070
Now, once you get your ACSP, you are now
an Apple Certified Support Professional.

78
00:04:01.070 --> 00:04:04.250
You've shown that you're able
to support Macs in a network.

79
00:04:04.250 --> 00:04:06.440
And if you wanna go the next step up,

80
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:10.170
the next step up is
the Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

81
00:04:10.170 --> 00:04:14.180
And this is designed not for somebody
who's just supporting Macs in the field,

82
00:04:14.180 --> 00:04:16.290
but somebody who's running
the IT department.

83
00:04:16.290 --> 00:04:20.720
You might not be the person that's
actually out there doing the grunt work,

84
00:04:20.720 --> 00:04:22.900
but you're the one calling
the shots on the bigger picture.

85
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:26.410
So, designing that overall infrastructure,
what solutions do I deploy?

86
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:27.930
That's the ACTC.

87
00:04:27.930 --> 00:04:32.043
And if you want to get your ACTC,
you have to have the ACSP first.

88
00:04:32.043 --> 00:04:36.171
You've gotta pass the ACSP, and
you've gotta pass the ACTC exam.

89
00:04:36.171 --> 00:04:41.140
And once you pass both of them, then you
get your ACTC, so you've gotta have both.

90
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:44.427
You can actually skip the ACA if you want,
you don't have to do those.

91
00:04:44.427 --> 00:04:48.028
If you have been working with Macs for
years and you're really comfortable with

92
00:04:48.028 --> 00:04:50.943
them, you can start right off with
the ACSP and jump right in it.

93
00:04:50.943 --> 00:04:55.351
But if you have no experience, you
wanna start at the ACA level first, and

94
00:04:55.351 --> 00:04:56.640
then jump up to ACSP.

95
00:04:56.640 --> 00:05:00.860
All right, so that's where this falls
in the Apple certification scheme,

96
00:05:00.860 --> 00:05:03.140
let's talk about what's on the exam.

97
00:05:03.140 --> 00:05:04.770
It covers a lot of great content,

98
00:05:04.770 --> 00:05:08.626
which are topics that are things that
we're gonna deal with in the real world.

99
00:05:08.626 --> 00:05:11.440
And I've kind of made a quick list here of
the topics that we cover in the show, so

100
00:05:11.440 --> 00:05:12.750
let's bring that up.

101
00:05:12.750 --> 00:05:14.810
We start with Installation and
Configuration.

102
00:05:14.810 --> 00:05:16.590
How do you get Mac OS installed?

103
00:05:16.590 --> 00:05:18.730
If you've only worked with
this in a home environment,

104
00:05:18.730 --> 00:05:21.860
you know that when you buy a Mac
it's already got Mac OS on it.

105
00:05:21.860 --> 00:05:24.460
But there's many times where you
might want to deploy it yourself.

106
00:05:24.460 --> 00:05:26.360
You might have 1,000 Macs that
are out there already and

107
00:05:26.360 --> 00:05:30.720
they're all running Mavericks, and you
need to get them upgraded to El Capitan.

108
00:05:30.720 --> 00:05:32.650
Or you might want to
build a standard image so

109
00:05:32.650 --> 00:05:35.780
that all your machines already have
software installed when you deploy them.

110
00:05:35.780 --> 00:05:37.130
We talk about that.

111
00:05:37.130 --> 00:05:38.580
Then we talk about User Accounts.

112
00:05:38.580 --> 00:05:42.160
Having individual user accounts on
everybody's computer is fine, but when

113
00:05:42.160 --> 00:05:46.030
you've got 1,000 computers, it's tough to
maintain that, it's tough to manage it.

114
00:05:46.030 --> 00:05:49.960
So having centralized user accounts and
special network type authentication

115
00:05:49.960 --> 00:05:52.960
is a really valuable thing to have,
so we talk about those.

116
00:05:52.960 --> 00:05:54.370
We talk about File Systems.

117
00:05:54.370 --> 00:05:58.140
When it comes to storage on a Mac,
it supports a number of different things.

118
00:05:58.140 --> 00:06:05.900
Internal and external storage, we have
our Apple OS X Extended Journal format.

119
00:06:05.900 --> 00:06:06.760
It's a big name.

120
00:06:06.760 --> 00:06:10.920
We have Microsoft's NTFS and FAT32 and
all these different file systems.

121
00:06:10.920 --> 00:06:13.530
And we talk about how they function inside
of the Mac, and how you can use them and

122
00:06:13.530 --> 00:06:15.810
some of the little caveats involved there.

123
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:18.910
We talk about Data Management,
just backing up our systems,

124
00:06:18.910 --> 00:06:22.070
keeping them healthy, keeping our
data safe, where to store data,

125
00:06:22.070 --> 00:06:25.220
how permissions work on our data
when it's on those file systems.

126
00:06:25.220 --> 00:06:28.150
Then we talked about Applications and
Processes.

127
00:06:28.150 --> 00:06:32.170
Mac OS is great, it's really easy to use,
but out of the box it doesn't have a ton

128
00:06:32.170 --> 00:06:34.670
of software in it, it's got all
the Apple software and that's about it.

129
00:06:34.670 --> 00:06:37.730
So you're likely going to have to
support third party applications, and

130
00:06:37.730 --> 00:06:38.670
we talk about that.

131
00:06:38.670 --> 00:06:42.060
How to get the applications loaded, how to
manage them, how to troubleshoot them when

132
00:06:42.060 --> 00:06:46.300
they start eating up too much CPU or too
much memory, we cover all that content.

133
00:06:46.300 --> 00:06:48.050
Then we jump into the networking world.

134
00:06:48.050 --> 00:06:51.220
How to get our system setup to
communicate on the network.

135
00:06:51.220 --> 00:06:54.130
And on the networking side,
we start off really with just IP networks.

136
00:06:54.130 --> 00:06:57.150
So how do you get two Macs to where
they can even see each other?

137
00:06:57.150 --> 00:06:59.290
And once they can see each
other on the network,

138
00:06:59.290 --> 00:07:00.650
then we move into Network Services.

139
00:07:00.650 --> 00:07:03.495
All right, great, your two computers
see each other, what do you do now?

140
00:07:03.495 --> 00:07:06.399
How can you share files,
how can you share folders,

141
00:07:06.399 --> 00:07:08.650
or printers, or even CD and DVD drives?

142
00:07:08.650 --> 00:07:11.840
How do you share any of those
resources when two computers see each

143
00:07:11.840 --> 00:07:12.690
other on the network?

144
00:07:12.690 --> 00:07:13.820
We cover all of that.

145
00:07:13.820 --> 00:07:17.090
And then we wrap up the show just
talking about System Management,

146
00:07:17.090 --> 00:07:20.950
and a better name for that section
would really be troubleshooting.

147
00:07:20.950 --> 00:07:24.270
What do you do when the Mac is not
behaving the way it's supposed to?

148
00:07:24.270 --> 00:07:27.900
We know it has all these great features
that are supposed to work like magic, but

149
00:07:27.900 --> 00:07:31.800
sometimes it just doesn't work out that
way and we've got to troubleshoot it.

150
00:07:31.800 --> 00:07:35.454
So I spend a lot of time in that
section covering all the really amazing

151
00:07:35.454 --> 00:07:39.935
troubleshooting tools that are built into
Mac OS and built into the Apple hardware.

152
00:07:39.935 --> 00:07:42.848
And it's part of what makes that
ecosystem so valuable to us.

153
00:07:42.848 --> 00:07:45.670
So those are the topics that we're gonna
be covering throughout this series.

154
00:07:45.670 --> 00:07:48.478
It's all broken up into 30 minute
episodes that are nice and

155
00:07:48.478 --> 00:07:50.120
easy to consume and watch.

156
00:07:50.120 --> 00:07:52.630
We cover it all,
it's a great certification.

157
00:07:52.630 --> 00:07:55.860
I really like this one because
it covers real world skills.

158
00:07:55.860 --> 00:07:58.850
Every one of these technologies are ones
that I've used in the real world.

159
00:07:58.850 --> 00:08:01.410
Sometime you get these certifications
where they cover technologies and

160
00:08:01.410 --> 00:08:02.130
you look at it and you're like, wow,

161
00:08:02.130 --> 00:08:06.130
this is more like a marketing slide,
I'm never gonna us this is real life.

162
00:08:06.130 --> 00:08:07.170
But this is stuff you will.

163
00:08:07.170 --> 00:08:10.000
Everything in here are things you'll
encounter on a regular basis, and

164
00:08:10.000 --> 00:08:11.880
it's excellent knowledge to know.

165
00:08:11.880 --> 00:08:14.453
So I encourage anybody who
supports Macs in a school or

166
00:08:14.453 --> 00:08:18.170
business environment, anywhere where
you have more than, say, ten Macs,

167
00:08:18.170 --> 00:08:22.390
it's really valuable to do
the certification, it's a great one to do.

168
00:08:22.390 --> 00:08:25.660
All right, so let's say you watched the
show, you learn all the great information,

169
00:08:25.660 --> 00:08:27.970
you're ready to take the test,
you wanna get certified.

170
00:08:27.970 --> 00:08:31.570
Well, the ACSP is a little
bit different than the ACA.

171
00:08:31.570 --> 00:08:34.070
The ACA exams,
the Mac Management Basics and

172
00:08:34.070 --> 00:08:37.780
Mac Integration Basics, you can take those
online from the comfort of your own home.

173
00:08:37.780 --> 00:08:40.770
You sign up right on Apple's website and
that's it.

174
00:08:40.770 --> 00:08:42.910
But with ACSP and ACTC,

175
00:08:42.910 --> 00:08:47.606
you can only take them at Apple
Authorized Training Centers, or AATCs.

176
00:08:47.606 --> 00:08:49.640
Now, there are AATCs all over the world,
so

177
00:08:49.640 --> 00:08:51.630
you just need to find one that's near you.

178
00:08:51.630 --> 00:08:54.550
And if you go to Apple's website,
if you go to training.apple.com,

179
00:08:54.550 --> 00:08:56.390
they've actually got a lot of
them located right on there.

180
00:08:56.390 --> 00:08:58.580
You can search and find them and
register for the exam.

181
00:08:58.580 --> 00:09:00.890
But the point is you've gotta
drive there to take it.

182
00:09:00.890 --> 00:09:03.620
So you've gotta go somewhere and
actually take this exam.

183
00:09:03.620 --> 00:09:06.050
The exam is two hours long,
so it's a long exam,

184
00:09:06.050 --> 00:09:07.940
you're gonna be in that
testing booth a while.

185
00:09:07.940 --> 00:09:12.080
It's got 80 questions, so it's about
a minute and a half per question.

186
00:09:12.080 --> 00:09:15.400
As long as you stick to that, you'll
come in on time and finish the exam.

187
00:09:15.400 --> 00:09:18.433
If you take more then a minute and a half
on a question then you might run out of

188
00:09:18.433 --> 00:09:21.142
time, right, so you've gotta stay
focused and move through it.

189
00:09:21.142 --> 00:09:24.260
Of the 80 questions,
there's 5 that aren't scored.

190
00:09:24.260 --> 00:09:27.378
They're kind of like demographic
survey-type questions where they're just

191
00:09:27.378 --> 00:09:30.100
testing out something, and
so they don't count those.

192
00:09:30.100 --> 00:09:31.470
But you don't know which five they are.

193
00:09:31.470 --> 00:09:33.670
So it really doesn't matter
that five of them are unscored,

194
00:09:33.670 --> 00:09:36.020
you need to do well on all of them.

195
00:09:36.020 --> 00:09:37.760
The questions are mostly multiple choice.

196
00:09:37.760 --> 00:09:39.760
You'll find that almost every
one is multiple choice.

197
00:09:39.760 --> 00:09:44.220
Some will be true and false, and
others might be a media experience,

198
00:09:44.220 --> 00:09:47.360
where it shows you a picture of
the system preferences screen.

199
00:09:47.360 --> 00:09:50.980
And it says click on the system
preference that does xyz task, and

200
00:09:50.980 --> 00:09:51.740
you've got to click on the one.

201
00:09:51.740 --> 00:09:54.920
So, its a graphical element
involved in the question.

202
00:09:54.920 --> 00:09:57.860
But the bulk of them are just multiple
choice and so you can use process of

203
00:09:57.860 --> 00:10:01.290
elimination and the other things we've
honed through years of public schooling,

204
00:10:01.290 --> 00:10:03.320
right, to figure out what
that right answer is.

205
00:10:03.320 --> 00:10:06.180
And I'll be honest with you guys,
this exam is really straightforward,

206
00:10:06.180 --> 00:10:09.070
there's no trick questions on there,
everything is really practical.

207
00:10:09.070 --> 00:10:12.830
It really is a great certification,
I've always been pleased with this one.

208
00:10:12.830 --> 00:10:14.430
It's a neat one.

209
00:10:14.430 --> 00:10:18.400
Now, the exam cost, I can't really
tell you that because it varies based

210
00:10:18.400 --> 00:10:19.940
on region, whichever country you're in.

211
00:10:19.940 --> 00:10:23.610
They have different pricing,
and so it can vary.

212
00:10:23.610 --> 00:10:25.980
But it's not a terribly expensive exam.

213
00:10:25.980 --> 00:10:32.000
The only hard part is having to go to
an AATC to take it, so just remember that.

214
00:10:32.000 --> 00:10:35.080
But, otherwise,
that's basically it for the exam.

215
00:10:35.080 --> 00:10:39.330
So I've talked about the ACSP
certification is, I've talked about what

216
00:10:39.330 --> 00:10:42.370
we're gonna cover on the show, all those
different topics that we need to know,

217
00:10:42.370 --> 00:10:45.670
I also talked about where
we can take the exam.

218
00:10:45.670 --> 00:10:49.730
The only other thing that I wannna mention
is that Apple has a really good study

219
00:10:49.730 --> 00:10:51.070
guide for the ACSP.

220
00:10:51.070 --> 00:10:54.040
Let me get back to their
website real quick, and

221
00:10:54.040 --> 00:10:58.450
on the page that I was showing you,
this is me at training.apple.com.

222
00:10:58.450 --> 00:11:03.690
So if you go to training.apple.com, you
can find the OS X Certifications section.

223
00:11:03.690 --> 00:11:08.180
And under OS X Certifications, you'll
find where it tells you about that exam.

224
00:11:08.180 --> 00:11:12.230
And over here to the side, you'll
see where it tells you to get ready,

225
00:11:12.230 --> 00:11:14.800
there's an El Capitan 101 Course.

226
00:11:14.800 --> 00:11:18.180
That's an official course you can
take at the AATCs if you want.

227
00:11:18.180 --> 00:11:20.590
And there's an Exam Preparation Guide.

228
00:11:20.590 --> 00:11:23.440
Download that guide, it's free,
it doesn't cost you a dime.

229
00:11:23.440 --> 00:11:24.230
You can download it.

230
00:11:24.230 --> 00:11:28.510
It is, I can't remember exactly how
long it is, about 75 pages, I think.

231
00:11:28.510 --> 00:11:31.860
And it tells you a little bit
about the exam and what to expect,

232
00:11:31.860 --> 00:11:34.500
some of the different things that
you can kind of expect to see.

233
00:11:34.500 --> 00:11:36.010
And that helps you to get ready.

234
00:11:36.010 --> 00:11:39.750
And between that and
the content that we cover in the show,

235
00:11:39.750 --> 00:11:41.560
you'll see the bulk of what's
gonna be on that exam.

236
00:11:41.560 --> 00:11:43.610
You'll be all prepared,
ready to go in there, and

237
00:11:43.610 --> 00:11:46.480
ready to pass and get your certification.

238
00:11:46.480 --> 00:11:48.720
So that's about it for the ACSP.

239
00:11:48.720 --> 00:11:52.040
If that sounds exciting to you,
something you wanna jump in and pursue,

240
00:11:52.040 --> 00:11:53.370
then you are in the right place.

241
00:11:53.370 --> 00:11:55.640
Stay tuned cuz our episodes are coming up.

242
00:11:55.640 --> 00:11:59.350
If it's not the right place for you, well,
if you're just getting started with Apple,

243
00:11:59.350 --> 00:12:01.260
definitely check out our ACA content.

244
00:12:01.260 --> 00:12:04.320
That Mac Management Basics is
a great show to start with.

245
00:12:04.320 --> 00:12:07.490
You can have never used an Apple
a single day in your life,

246
00:12:07.490 --> 00:12:09.740
jump right into Mac Management Basics,
and you'll fit right in.

247
00:12:09.740 --> 00:12:13.630
Get through that, and then come over
here to ACSP, it'll be a great fit.

248
00:12:13.630 --> 00:12:16.970
It's all part of the ITProTV library so
you have access to it.

249
00:12:16.970 --> 00:12:19.370
Just jump over there and
tackle it, it's great content.

250
00:12:19.370 --> 00:12:22.280
If Apple's not your cup of tea,
if this doesn't sound right for you,

251
00:12:22.280 --> 00:12:24.060
then be sure to check out
the rest of our library.

252
00:12:24.060 --> 00:12:27.860
We've got all sorts of training
content for all different areas of IT.

253
00:12:27.860 --> 00:12:31.260
Not just Apple, but also Microsoft, Linux,
and other vendors that are out there,

254
00:12:31.260 --> 00:12:33.160
definitely things that
you'll wanna check out.

255
00:12:33.160 --> 00:12:37.814
But for those of you that sticking with me
for the ACSP, I think I've rattled on long

256
00:12:37.814 --> 00:12:41.485
enough, so stay tuned,
our episodes are kicking up after this.

257
00:12:41.485 --> 00:12:49.209
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don cover the steps a user should take prior to installing OS X El Capitan on their system. They cover downloading the El Capitan installer, creating a USB installable media, and other required steps.
episodes.title: Getting Prepared

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don walk through installing OS X El Capitan on a machine. They also discuss various disk partitioning options to support data separation and boot camp.
episodes.title: Installing El Capitan

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at what to do when your Mac doesn't "just work." They demonstrate how to use the built-in recovery partition found on most Macs, as well as some alternatives for Macs not featuring a recovery partition.
episodes.title: OS Recovery

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don cover the configuration items that most users will take immediately after installing Mac OS X. They cover how to migrate user data from a previous installation whether it be a Windows PC or another machine running Mac.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on the configuration items that most users will take immediately after installing Mac OS X. They demonstrate the steps to get a freshly installed Mac OS X operating system connected to the network. They look at the different steps to get wired and wireless network connection configured.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on the configuration items that most users will take immediately after installing Mac OS X. They demonstrate using the Setup Assistant to easily configure the intial settings needed to get started with Mac OS X. They will look configuration profiles and managing updates through the App Store.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don discuss how user accounts function in Mac OS X. They talk about the types of user accounts that are inside of 10.11 and demonstrate how to create a user account. They also take a look at the System Preferences user interface.
episodes.title: Managing User Accounts

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on how user accounts function in Mac OS X. They take a look at a user's home folder including the content such as Desktop, Documents, Downloads, Library and more. They will demonstrate how to delete a user account as well as restoring a deleted user account.
episodes.title: Managing User Accounts Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don highlight the differences between using a Mac with a single user account, versus sharing a system with multiple users. They demonstrate how to quickly move between users with Fast User Switching and ends the show discussion some of the security concerns that come along with sharing your machine.
episodes.title: Multiple User Accounts

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don tackle additional security options available for user accounts under Mac OS X El Capitan. They cover firmware passwords, iCloud accounts, secure password storage, using keychain, and FileVault drive encryption.
episodes.title: User Account Security

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don introduce us to the ways Mac OS handles disks and their associated data. They discuss the types of media options when supporting OS X including internal and external as well as removeable media types.
episodes.title: File Storage

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don introduce us to the ways Mac OS handles disks and their associated data. They detail the various file systems supported by El Capitan and demonstrating how to prepare adrive for use and walks us through some troubleshooting procedure should the need arise.
episodes.title: File Storage Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don demonstrate encrypting disks using FileVault v2. They also explain how to upgrade from the original FileVault. They end the episode by discussing how to securely erase files from the hard drive.
episodes.title: Securing Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain file permissions in concept and practice in Mac OS 10.11. They start by explaining the types of objects that will be affected by permissions, specifically being the User/Owner, Groups, and Other users. Then they look at what permissions can be set and define them. All this is shown in both the Graphical Interface and the Command Line.
episodes.title: File Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue their look at file permissions in Mac OS 10.11, here picking up with how to set and change permissions using the GUI and the command line option of "chmod". They also show you how to change the owner of a file by using the "chown" command. Finally they set extended permissions using Access Control List, working both from the CLI and GUI.
episodes.title: File Permissions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don complete their coverage of file permissions by diving into the Home folder structure and default permissions. They look at default folders in the Home directory, like the Public folder which is used for sharing data with other users. They also look at the Shared folder which performs similarly to the Public folder. They also show you how to retain file permissions and protect against deletion by setting the "sticky bit". And finally they show you how to repair permissions that have be damaged as well as working with the file systems on removable media.
episodes.title: File Permissions Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the magical world of managing files in Mac OS 10.11. They begin the journey by discussing Aliases and Links. Both are magical ways to access a file or folder from a different location; each having its pros and cons. They also look at application files called Bundles and system packages.
episodes.title: Managing Files

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue looking at file management in Mac OS 10.11. Here they explain how to work with and create hidden system files and folders. They also show you the 4 file domains which includes the User, Local, Network, and System domains. Finally they guide you through some important system resources like extensions, fonts, frameworks, logs, preferences, and Startup items.
episodes.title: Managing Files Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to utilize the built-in file archiving and disk imaging systems. These systems will allow you to bundle files together into one file, as well as provide options like compression, encryption, and compatibility with other systems.
episodes.title: Archives and Images

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to backup your data using the Mac OS 10.11 utility, Time Machine. Here they show you how to setup Time Machine on an external hard drive and walk you through it's use.
episodes.title: Time Machine

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to install applications on a Mac OS 10.11 system through the App Store or Side-Loading. They explain the pros and cons of installing apps through both methods and explain the steps you'll encounter in the process. They also show you how to enable or disable dashboard widgets.
episodes.title: Managing Applicaitons

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the topic of application data in Mac OS 10.11. They begin by showing you where application preferences are stored, which are saved as .plist files. They also show you how to protect files by locking them. Finally, they show you how Mac OS X knows what program to use to open the different file types.
episodes.title: Application Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue their look at application data in Mac OS 10.11, picking up with a handy feature called quick look which allows you to preview a file before opening. Finally, they demonstrate the auto-save feature, showing you how to enable/disable and resume which takes the user back to the previous state when app was last closed.
episodes.title: Application Data Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain some of the applications you might need to support in Mac OS 10.11. They begin by taking a look at Java. They show you how to install Java and describe when/why you may need a Java environment on your system. They they move on to iCloud; showing you how to get iCloud setup and working with other applications.
episodes.title: Application Support

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue discussing Application Support in Mac OS. The pick up here by looking at Voice and Accessibility options, specifically VoiceOver and Dictation&Speech. They show you how to enable and configure VoiceOver to perform Text-to-Speech functions. Then they show you how to enable and configure Dictation which takes input from the user's verbal commands.
episodes.title: Application Support Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don finish their exposition on Application Support in Mac OS 10.11 and here they begin with looking at the Mac OS itself. They talk about the benefits of El Capitan when working with Apps. They also talk more about Application Sandboxing. Finally, they go over monitoring by discussing the Activity Monitor, System Information, and Diagnostic Reporting.
episodes.title: Application Support Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don demonstrate and explain networking concepts and practices in El Capitan. They begin by laying out the foundational knowledge of how networking works. They detail the language or "Protocols" that network devices speak which is typically TCP/IP and the addressing schemes that are utilized by IP version 4(IPv4) and IPv6. They also talk about the physical components of a network.
episodes.title: Network Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue their discussion of networking in a Mac OS X environment. Here they pick back up with explaining how network client machines get their IP information using the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) as well as setting IP info manually. They also explain some of the other protocols being utilized like Domain Name System(DNS) and Address Resolution Protocol(ARP).
episodes.title: Network Configuration Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the various network settings involved in configuring a Mac to communicate on a wireless network. He begins by discussing authentication and then moves on to common settings and basic troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Network Configuration Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Don concludes the network configuration section of the ACSP. This episode focuses on troubleshooting methodology and tools for use when a network connection is not functioning. He demonstrates configuring network locations, VPN connections and using the Network Utility to troubleshoot networks.
episodes.title: Network Configuration Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates using the iCloud services in OS X. He starts the show with basic configuration and authentication. He then moves on to cover Back to My Mac and the iCloud KeyChain, spending extra time to explain the security concerns with each.
episodes.title: Using iCloud

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the multiple ways in which OS X can share resources on a network. He demonstrates screen sharing and the multiple protocols available for file sharing.
episodes.title: Sharing Resources

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues covering shared resources in OS X. He demonstrates using Apple Remote Desktop to remotely manage and update OS X client on the network. He also shows how ARD can be used to replace screen sharing for centralized management. Finally, he describes troubleshooting shared resources.
episodes.title: Sharing Resources Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the various peripheral devices supported by OS X 10.11 El Capitan. He shows how to determine what devices are connected, and how to verify hardware and software functionality. He also demonstrates how OS X uses system integrity protection to ensure unsigned drivers are not installed.
episodes.title: Peripheral Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks the viewers through configuring printers on a Mac. He demonstrates using local and network enabled printers. He wraps up the show demonstrating trouble shooting procedures.
episodes.title: Supporting Printers

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses the boot process for OS X. He explains each step and highlights some of the problems that can arise as the boot process continues. He demonstrates the Safe Mode, Safe Boot, Single User Mode, Verbose Mode trouble shooting tools.
episodes.title: System Troubleshooting

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues discussing the boot process for OS X. He explains each step and highlights some of the problems that can arise as the boot process continues. He demonstrates the Safe Mode, Safe Boot, Single User Mode, Verbose Mode trouble shooting tools.
episodes.title: System Troubleshooting Part 2
